title: [Large-scale] Online Health Information Digital Literacy Enhancement Course: Developing Civic Health Decision-making Competencies

context.prior_knowledge: Basic internet search abilities and digital device usage experience, and awareness of health information accessibility as a community member
context.additional_context: Designed for learners in administrative/leadership roles, the program aims to enhance their ability to evaluate and utilize health information in workplace settings. Conducted in a BYOD (Bring Your Own Device) environment, it measures learning outcomes through project-based assessments, with a focus on information literacy skills for promoting community health and advancing civic rights.

learning_goals: Learners can classify online health information with over 80% accuracy by applying five core criteria for evaluating credibility (source, evidence, recency, objectivity, expert verification), thereby cultivating critical evaluation skills as informed citizens.

Learners revise their health information analysis reports at least three times based on peer feedback in a digital literacy discussion forum and include a plan for applying their findings to real-world work environments when submitting their final projects, strengthening their capacity to share health information within social networks.

Within four weeks after training, learners submit two case studies of health information-based decision-making from actual work settings that meet evaluation criteria, contributing to institutional health policy improvements and the design of community health promotion projects.

resources: Access to reliable health information database

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
